creator: hopf@synyx.de
text:
The Option for adding an HttpCookieManager is not available when run under Kubuntu with jdk 1.6.0_13. No indication of a failure in the logs, it's just not there. Running a normal test works.

When running with jdk  1.5.0_13 the option is there and can be used normally.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text: Is there a failure reported in the console window?

creator: hopf@synyx.de
text:
Created attachment 25003
log file with ClassNotFoundException for commons-logging

I am starting the application with jmeter.sh, no output is logged to the console where I started it.

I just reviewed the log file, it complains about class not found for commons-logging, which is available in the lib directory.
creator: hopf@synyx.de

text:
The class org/apache/commons/logging/LogFactory is used by lots of JMeter classes, so it does not make sense for it to only be reported for CookieManager.

Are you using the same installation of JMeter for both JVMs?
Are you using any property overrides for logging?
creator: sebb@apache.org
hopf@synyx.de
text:
I am using the same installation for both, just replacing the java runtime does the trick.

I did not modify any of the config files, the installation is downloaded, unpacked and started.

I tried several version:
jakarta-jmeter-2.2: Entry is displayed but ClassNotFound-Exception is displayed when trying to add it to a Thread-Group
jakarta-jmeter-2.3: Entry is not displayed
jakarta-jmeter-2.3.1: Entry is not displayed
jakarta-jmeter-2.3.4: Entry is not displayed

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
I don't have any problems in Win/XP with

java.version=1.6.0_17                  
java.vm.name=Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM

So in theory it's most likely to be a problem with Java.

Is there a more recent version of Java 1.6 for Kubuntu?

creator: milamber@apache.org
text:
I don't have this problem with a fresh kubuntu 9.10 64bits install. JMeter Cookie manager works.

* with sun-java6-jdk 1.6u15 from ubuntu repository
* and with jdk-6u13-linux-x64.bin from Sun java website

check your PATH and CLASSPATH?

creator: hopf@synyx.de
text:
It also works for me when downloading a fresh version of jdk 1.6.0_18 so I would consider this as fixed.

Thanks a lot for your help, maybe this can at least be useful as a reference for somebody else.
